data.title: Add option to fail Publish Test Results task when test result file is not found
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: PublishTestResults@2  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

I imagine it is a common pattern to have a test task (with continueOnError: true) followed by a publish task. I've run into the issue a couple times where we will have our test task fail due to setup issues (e.g. not test failures), but the junit output file will not be published. The PublishTestResults task will warn it cannot find the file, but it will not fail the task. I find myself relying heavily on `failTaskOnFailedTests: true`, and wish that I could make this task fail if no output files are found.

### Task logs

For our build setup see [here](https://dev.azure.com/reason-native/reason-native/_build/results?buildId=665). This particular log actually brings up another issue, where failing when the output cannot be parsed would also be nice. I don't think we have a log with the issue I described at the moment, but both things have occurred.

data.title: Allow dotnet test with publish --results-directory to be customized
data.body:
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: .NET Core - test

## Environment
Server - Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

Checking the **Publish test results and code coverage** option sets --results-directory to the agent's temporary directory, making it difficult to isolate a single build's test output when publishing the results of multiple data collectors.

Recommendation: Allow --results-directory to be overridden (via textbox) when **Publish test results and code coverage** is checked.

This would allow users to harvest the output for publishing to additional code coverage tools or overcome shortcomings in the existing tooling (such as the code coverage tab only providing a link instead of an html report).

data.title: Fix "No credentials are available in the security package"
data.body:
Add `<add key="ValidAuthenticationTypes" value="basic"/>` to the package source credentials to prevent nuget/dotnet from trying to authenticate via NTLM/Windows authentication.

This fixes #11768 and the second problem that is described in #10399 next to the feed name encoding problem.

data.title: [Feature Request] XCode5 Legacy Build System
data.body:
**FEATURE REQUEST**

Starting from XCode 10, the legacy build system is deprecated and the New build system is the default.

So I want a new checkbox or property called:
UseModernBuildSystem: false

and it should behave like adding a new argument to xcode command
```-UseModernBuildSystem=0```
or
```-UseModernBuildSystem=NO```


**Actual yaml**
```
- task: Xcode@5
  inputs:
    actions: 'build'
    configuration: 'Release'
    sdk: 'iphoneos'
    xcWorkspacePath: 'something.xcworkspace'
    scheme: 'Something'
    packageApp: false
    args: '-UseModernBuildSystem=0'
```


**Proposed yaml**

```
- task: Xcode@5
  inputs:
    actions: 'build'
    configuration: 'Release'
    sdk: 'iphoneos'
    xcWorkspacePath: 'something.xcworkspace'
    scheme: 'Something'
    packageApp: false
    useModernBuildSystem: false
```

data.title: Python Twine Upload Authenticate problem when feed name contains dot.
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
Bug

**Enter Task Name**: Python Twine Authenticate v0/v1 (I checked both versions)

## Environment
Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description
If a seed artifact contains a dot, for instance, "My.Feed", the task "Python Twine Upload Authenticate" will create the ".pypirc" as follows:

```
[distutils]
index-servers=My.Feed
[My\.Feed]
repository=https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/myorganization/_packaging/My.Feed/pypi/upload
username=build
password=***
```

This involves that the execution of "twine upload -r My.Feed --config-file $(PYPIRC_PATH) dist/*" fails since it cannot found the "My.Feed" section in the .pypirc file.

## Troubleshooting
The solution was using this command after the execution of the task:

```
sed -i -e 's/\\//g' $(PYPIRC_PATH)
```

### Error logs

```
2019-10-07T17:05:21.5496516Z [command]/bin/bash --noprofile --norc /home/vsts/work/_temp/<hidden-info>.sh
2019-10-07T17:05:21.9224804Z InvalidConfiguration: Missing 'My.Feed' section from the configuration file
2019-10-07T17:05:21.9226042Z or not a complete URL in --repository-url.
2019-10-07T17:05:21.9227166Z Maybe you have a out-dated '/home/vsts/work/_temp/twineAuthenticate/oswDqH/.pypirc' format?
2019-10-07T17:05:21.9227404Z more info: https://docs.python.org/distutils/packageindex.html#pypirc
```

unable to get local issuer certificate
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: DownloadSecureFileV1 / InstallSSHKeyV0   

## Environment
- TFS on-premises
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 

About Azure DevOps Server
Version Dev17.M153.3

- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
private Linux agent running Azure Pipelines agent v2.158
    
## Issue Description

Both tasks fail with infamous 'unable to get local issuer certificate'. server certificate is added to system-wide cert store - agent does not complain when connecting to the queue nor git complains when fetching sources.
I established that the source of an error is NodeJS bundled with Azure pipelines agent. 
For some reason it does not fetch system-wide SSL certificates, it seems to use cert store bundled with NodeJS only. 
It does not help that Azure Pipelines agent is bundled with NodeJS v6.10.3 - some additional SSL/TLS related configuration options were introduced in 6.11 and more recently in NodeJS v7 and above.

I found few workarounds that do work, but nothing that could last.

1. export NODE_EXTRA_CA_CERTS=/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
export SSL_CERT_DIR=/etc/ssl/certs and run agent interactively with ./run.sh. This option still did not work for agent configured as service despite adding exports above to user profile

2. add the following at the beginning of bin/AgentService.js:
process.env.NODE_EXTRA_CA_CERTS='/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt';
process.env.SSL_CERT_DIR='/etc/ssl/certs';

This will only last as long the agent will not be updated / reinstalled from server.

I am looking for a proper fix.

## Environment

Any environment where the Xcode task can be used.

## Issue Description

During the Xcode export process, it's not possible to specify options for `compileBitcode`, `thinning`, and more (see full list [here](https://gist.github.com/cocoaNib/502900f24846eb17bb29)). This is particularly painful for us because compiling bitcode for our Ad Hoc builds is completely unnecessary and adds 5+ minutes to the build time.

data.title: DownloadPackagesV1 may report success, even if the download fails
data.body:
## Required Information
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  Bug
*Type*: Error handling
**Enter Task Name**: DownloadPackagesV1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description
Customer reported that in a build, the actual download failed with a message "UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 1): Failed to extract package with error Error: Could not find the End of Central Directory Record", _but_ the task still completed without error.

The task needs to handle, and correctly report errors in the download promise.

Additionally, add some debug logging before and after the `download`/`process` calls

data.title: CopyFilesOverSSH:  Update nested dependencies to fix copying to Solaris 11
data.body: Currently, the **CopyFilesOverSSH** task uses scp2 which depends on ssh2 which uses ssh2-streams.  About 2 years ago, a [change went into ssh2-streams](https://github.com/mscdex/ssh2-streams/commit/09c5884eccd702eb0723b319966c8018d9e06fde) to fix a bug that caused the SSH connection with Solaris 11 to hang.  Unfortunately, scp2 is not well maintained and it still uses an older version of ssh2 that doesn't use the updated ssh2-streams package.  This PR uses npm shrinkwrap to specify the nested dependencies for our task to force scp2 to use the updated ssh2 0.8.2 used elsewhere in the task.  Local testing shows compatibility and successfully copies files over SSH from Windows to a Ubuntu VM on Azure.

data.title: [NpmAuthenticate] Local credentials not loaded for working file not named .npmrc
data.body:
## Overview

- **Type**: Bug
- **Task Name**: NPM Authenticate
- **Server**: Azure Pipelines
- **Agent**: Hosted Ubuntu 1604

## Issue Description

When running the NPM Authenticate task with a `workingFile` whose leaf file name is something other than `.npmrc`, local credentials are never loaded into the file.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3675357/66018271-40cccd80-e493-11e9-9180-8774a00d29eb.png)

I can confirm that changing the path from `build.npmrc` to `.npmrc` in both the repository and the task configuration makes things work.

This appears to derive from the following combination of factors:

- The working directory is extracted from the `workingFile` here. It does not assume that the file name is specifically `.npmrc`, just checks that it _ends with_ `.npmrc`.

  https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/406bcf9cdbd05b3dd9709cb90ee8a5797d5d25c0/Tasks/NpmAuthenticateV0/npmauth.ts#L16-L20

- However, when that directory is passed down to `npmutil.ts` in the `getLocalNpmRegistries()` function, a file path is generated which assumes that the file's name is `.npmrc`, rather than the name of the file that was provided in `workingFile`.

  https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/406bcf9cdbd05b3dd9709cb90ee8a5797d5d25c0/Tasks/Common/packaging-common/npm/npmutil.ts#L56-L61

- As a result, the log is outputting that it couldn't find any credentials for the endpoint:

  ```
  No service connections that matched pkgs.dev.azure.com were found
  ```

data.title: Index Sources & Publish Symbols fails with TF400813: Resource not available for anonymous access. Client authentication required.

labels.name: regression
labels.description: This used to work, but a change in the service/tasks broke it.

data.body:
## Required Information

**Type**: **Bug**
**Enter Task Name**: **Index Sources & Publish Symbols**

## Environment
- Server - TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 17.143.28912.1

- Agent - Private
    
    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 


Capability name | Capability value
-- | --
Agent.OS | Windows_NT
Agent.OSVersion | 10.0.14393
Agent.Version | 2.131.0


## Issue Description

Running the task results in the described error. Looking at the task code, the following execution flow emerges:

1. The code reaches https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/c5de8d6beb30280eae54e6f0c2a17bb59ad98d92/Tasks/PublishSymbolsV2/PublishSymbols.ps1#L175-L177 and discovers that there is no account name, no PAT and Aad is not used. 
1. So, the code executes https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/c5de8d6beb30280eae54e6f0c2a17bb59ad98d92/Tasks/PublishSymbolsV2/PublishSymbols.ps1#L19-L20, sending an unauthenticated request to the on-premises Azure DevOps server.

This is strange. I would expect it at least to pass `-UseDefaultCredentials`. As it is now, the request is aborted, which is totally expected.

In effect, it makes it impossible to publish symbols to the on premises Azure DevOps server.

### Task logs

[log_6_588891.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/3655069/log_6_588891.zip)


### Error logs

`TF400813: Resource not available for anonymous access. Client authentication required. - Azure DevOps Server`

data.title: AppCenterDistribute: Possibly wrong hardcoded link
data.body:
Hi,

I tried to use this task but I got 404 error. Looking into debug info, i can see that from the pipeline the link i got is this:
`https://appcenter.ms/orgs/XYZ/apps/XYZ/release_uploads`
XYZ - hidden by me
And indeed, when accessing the above link from the browser, i got a 404 error. However, getting to the link via the web page, i'm getting to this link:
`https://appcenter.ms/orgs/XYZ/apps/XYZ/distribute/releases`

So we have **release_uploads** vs **distribute/releases**.
Is it possible that the link has changed in the last few months in App Center and the azure task wasn't updated meanwhile? The hardcoded code is here:
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/699a04b379aeb120a55debd49cb355ee408566a6/Tasks/AppCenterDistributeV3/appcenterdistribute.ts#L97

Thank you!

data.title: Azure SQL DacpacTask v1.0 ignores DoNotDropObjectTypes
data.body:
*Type*: Question, possibly a bug

**Enter Task Name**: Azure SQL DacpacTask  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted 

## Issue Description

I have two Azure SQL servers/databases, one of which acts as a Dev db (the source) and another a Test db (the target). The database in target is currently identical to that in the source, including login and user identifiers. I have extracted a DACPAC file from the source. I have a simple build pipeline which adds the DACPAC file into deployment artifact. Then I have a simple release pipeline which is set as follows:

A single hosted agent job with vs2017-win2016 spec, pulls up the artifact from the build
The agent job includes a single task Azure SQL DacpacTask, v1.0, which
uses ARM connection type
successfully working azure subscription registration
fully qualified URI for Azure db (the target)
correct db name

data.title: [DotNetCoreCLIV2] Add vstest action to .NET Core CLI task
data.body:
The .NET Core CLI task supports a range of commands:

``` YAML
#command: 'build' # Options: build, push, pack, publish, restore, run, test, custom
```

... but not "**vstest**".

However, "vstest" is pretty common and vital these days:

* Using action="custom" works, but you need to know the arguments to create a .TRX files.
* It feels like a (dirty) workaround, as you need to take care yourself about storing and publishing the test results via a .TRX file
* Using the VSTest task as an alternative is not an option when running on a non-windows OS.

So: please add support for "**dotnet vstest**" like a first-class citizen (similar to "**dotnet test**").

Thanks,
--Neno

data.title: Tasks do not emit errors in the same way their command-line equivalents do, causing unexpected behaviour
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: NuGetCommand@2, PublishBuildArtifacts@1, many others

## Environment
- Server: Azure Pipelines
- Agent: Hosted

## Issue Description

My company has a project, originally in .NET Framework, that was built into a NuGet package via a build pipeline in Azure DevOps. The package was created via a nuspec file and the `nuget pack` task:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1726434/63840956-d1d2f500-c979-11e9-93e6-c4dac45dd250.png)

This project was migrated to .NET Standard but the nuspec was retained. I then deleted the nuspec file (as that package metadata is now built into the .NET Standard/Core csproj file format, making the nuspec redundant) but neglected to update the task to look at the csproj instead of the nuspec.

The result is that when the build is run, the `nuget pack` task looks for a nonexistent nuspec file, and of course doesn't find it. But... it doesn't have any problem with that fact. It doesn't error, it doesn't even warn, it just completes successfully. I had to set `system.debug = true` to even get any inkling of a problem ("Found 0 files", [see attached log file](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/3550092/task.log)).

The end result is that no NuGet package is created, which means that the subsequent "Publish artifacts" task does nothing. Which means our release pipeline's `nuget push` does nothing. Which means that no NuGet package is uploaded to our feed. Which makes my clients unhappy. Which makes me very unhappy.

Did I mention that there are no errors at any stage of this process? The artifact publish and NuGet push at least give warnings - but warnings don't fail a pipeline, nor can they be made to.

Even better, if I do the following on my local machine:

```
> nuget pack <project-name>/<project-name>.nuspec
```

I get:

```
Attempting to build package from '<project-name>.nuspec'.
Error NU5008: Manifest file not found at 'C:\Projects\<project-name>\<project-name>.nuspec'
```

In other words, nuget.exe fails hard when it can't find the specific file it's asked to pack with, but the Azure Pipelines NuGet task doesn't. Why is the behaviour different?

More to the point, why are you guys so apparently averse to emitting errors from your tasks, especially when the "Continue on error" checkbox exists? Warnings are not acceptable, because a file that is not found almost certainly means that there is a problem with the pipeline configuration, and I want to know about a problem as soon as it happens, not have to go hunting through logs to find it after the fact.

It isn't Azure's place to decide whether a missing file is fine or not, it's mine. And currently I have no option to make that decision. So you need to add it.

## Fix

1. The `nuget pack` Azure Pipelines task must behave identically to its command-line counterpart when confronted with a path that doesn't exist. In other words, instead of doing nothing, it should give a very explicit error, then terminate.
2. All tasks that deal with file paths must have a boolean option (default false) to fail immediately if the provided file path or glob expression yields no matching files.
3. All tasks must have a boolean option (default false) to treat warnings as errors.

data.title: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment: can't control exported bacpac location
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment  

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/SqlAzureDacpacDeploymentV1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted or Private: N/A, both

## Issue Description

When using the `export` `deploymentAction`, there's no way to control where the output file goes. It always goes to `GeneratedOutputFiles\myDatabase.bacpac` inside the source tree.

I tried supplying `/TargetFile:` but that resulted in a duplicate argument error:
```
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Enterprise\Common7\IDE\Extensions\Microsoft\SQLDB\DAC\150\SqlPackage.exe" /Action:Export /TargetFile:"C:\agent\_work\3\s\GeneratedOutputFiles\myDatabase.bacpac" /SourceServerName:"myDatabase.database.windows.net" /SourceDatabaseName:"myDatabase" /SourceUser:"myDatabase" /SourcePassword:"********" /p:AllowIncompatiblePlatform=true /TargetFile:C:\agent\_work\_temp\\prod_backup.bacpac
```

I also tried using the `dacpacFile` or `bacpacFile` inputs, but that didn't change behavior either, and didn't result in errors - the most logical choice would probably be `bacpacFile` for the `export` `deploymentAction`.

The only workaround is to live with the default path and use the `SqlDeploymentOutputFile` output variable to determine where it lives and delete it afterward. Unfortunately, this makes it impossible to do cleanup at the beginning of a pipeline.

1. Set Active Cloud
2. az login with service principal associated with the service connection
3. Perform an az account set to a subscription

Step #3 fails when service connections is scoped for a management group because there is no subscription specified.  It runs:

> az account set --subscription <undefined>

The whole pipeline fails before even getting to specified code or script in the CLI task.

data.title: dotnet publish task uses directory as project name, not actual project name
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLI@2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

We have a classic/non-YAML build pipeline that has a .NET Core task to publish our artifacts. This task has the "Add project name to publish path" checkbox ticked because the solution being built has multiple projects, and we want to publish all of them:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1726434/63097410-419fb380-bf68-11e9-81a6-6a5357a7d7f6.png)

Previously our solution was structured as so:

```
\Foo.Service\Foo.Service.csproj
\Bar.Service\Bar.Service.csproj
```

and the publish task worked correctly because it placed the build output of the two projects into `$(Build.StagingDirectory)\Foo.Service` and `$(Build.StagingDirectory)\Bar.Service`, which were then zipped to `Foo.Service.zip` and `Bar.Service.zip`. All good.

However we recently refactored the solution so it's structured like this:

```
\Foo\Service\Foo.Service.csproj
\Bar\Service\Bar.Service.csproj
```

and now the publish creates `$(Build.StagingDirectory)\Service` for Foo.Service, which then immediately gets nuked because Bar.Service also ends up in `$(Build.StagingDirectory)\Service`, so I end up with a single `Service.zip` which only contains `Bar.Service`. Not so good.

It appears that instead of using the **project filename minus the extension** when "Add project name to publish path" is checked, this task is using the project **directory**, which is incorrect.

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Hosted: 
    
## Issue Description

Given the following YAML, the first download step in `jobB` fails due to the variable not being expanded, but the second one expands and succeeds. I would expect them both to succeed.

```yaml
variables:
  system.debug: true
jobs:
  - job: jobA
    variables:
      artifactName: qwe
    steps:
      - publish: $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)
        artifact: $(artifactName)
  - job: jobB
    dependsOn: jobA
    variables:
      artifactName: $[dependencies.jobA.outputs['outputVars.artifactName']]
    steps:
      - download: current
        artifact: $[dependencies.jobA.outputs['outputVars.artifactName']]
```

data.title: DockerV2 Docker Registry (ACR) Service Connection Problems
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question

**Enter Task Name**: DockerV2  

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/DockerV2

## Issue Description

The requirement to now use the Container Registry Service Connection for Azure Container Registry connections from the DockerV2 task requires the user creating the connection to have both permissions to create a Service Principal and assign it permissions to the ACR itself.

This causes problems for us as we don't want to randomly create ad-hoc Service Principals / Application IDs whenever we want to connect a new service connection. Also the automation which creates the connection will more than likely not have the permissions to do both.

We are currently using V1 which allows usage of a pre-existing Service Principal registered with the AzureRM Service Connection, although I've seen you are moving away from this (#10811), I think this is a major mistake as the majority of the time all services deployed from a pipeline on Azure will be reusing the existing Azure RM service connection.

**This causes major headaches if we were to need to maintain a different service connection type every time we need to connect to a different resource type in Azure**, which is the logical conclusion of the decision you've made.

There is another request related to this over in the Azure DevOps CLI project here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-devops-cli-extension/issues/706 

Can you please fix this in one of these ways (preferred order)?

1. Update the DockerV2 Task to support either AzureRM or Docker Registry connection types
2. Allow the new Docker Registry service connection to reference the existing Azure RM service connection (nested) when using the Azure Container Registry type
3. Allow an existing service principal to be registered as the service connection for Docker Registry ACR types (without it having to generate it on the fly)

Thanks for your help with this.

data.title: FileTransformV1 doesn't support using variables starting with "Build." or "System."
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
Bug

**Task Name**: FileTransformV1

## Environment
- Server: Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted, ubuntu-16.04

## Issue Description

Using the [File Transform task](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/utility/file-transform?view=azure-devops) to replace values in a JSON file:

```yaml
  jobs:
  - job: CI_Build
    pool:
      vmImage: 'ubuntu-16.04'

    variables:
      # Set build variables written to build-metadata.json file
      Build.Id: $(Build.BuildId)
      Build.PipelineName: $(System.DefinitionName)
      Build.JobName: $(System.JobDisplayName)
      Build.Timestamp: $(System.PipelineStartTime)

    steps:
    - task: FileTransform@1
      displayName: 'Update build-meta.json file'
      inputs:
        folderPath: 'build'
        fileType: json
        targetFiles: 'build-metadata.json'
```

And a `build-metadata.json` JSON file like:

```json
{
  "Build": {
    "Id": "-1",
    "PipelineName": "??",
    "JobName": "??",
    "Timestamp": "2018-08-01 16:13:00-07:00"
  },
  "GitVersion": {
    "SemVer": "0.1.0-dev",
    "Sha": "??????????????????????????????????",
    "ShortSha": "???????",
    "BranchName": "??"
  }
}
```

I expected all the JSON property values to be filled in. The values within my `GitVersion` block were filled in as expected; the values within my `Build` block were not. 

There is no apparent good reason to prevent the use of `Build` or `System` variables in the FileTransform task. If there is, then the reason should be documented, and a task property/setting should exist that enables replacing properties with "well known" prefixes.

### Task logs

No log output shows variables that aren't replaced, so logging isn't helpful here.

I determined that a bug exists by reviewing the source:

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/ccb5852d8d2cd714879559da2013b9211c381966/Tasks/Common/webdeployment-common-v2/jsonvariablesubstitutionutility.ts#L21
```ts
        if(varUtility.isPredefinedVariable(envVariable.name)) {
            continue;
        } 
```

and https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/ccb5852d8d2cd714879559da2013b9211c381966/Tasks/Common/webdeployment-common/variableutility.ts#L3
```ts
export function isPredefinedVariable(variable: string): boolean {
    var predefinedVarPrefix = ['agent.', 'azure_http_user_agent', 'build.', 'common.', 'release.', 'system', 'tf_'];
    for(let varPrefix of predefinedVarPrefix) {
        if(variable.toLowerCase().startsWith(varPrefix)) {
            return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}
```

shows that any variables with this set of common prefixes are dropped on the ground, and not logged. From the standpoint of developers trying to insert values into files, these exclusions are arbitrary, mysterious, and problematic.

data.title: Add logging command to upload pipeline artifacts.
data.body:
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Logging commands

## Issue Description

The artifact.upload command is very slow compared to using pipeline artifacts steps. I guess it uses "legacy" build artifacts as opposed to pipeline artifacts and the optimisations that comes with them.

I would like to be able to use pipeline artifacts from logging commands for convenience (trigger artifacts upload directly from a MSBuild target in my case).

data.title: Selective Module Loading on AzurePowerShell
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: AzurePowerShell

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description
Each time I use the task, in the same pipeline, the entire Az/AzureRM module is loaded, making it VERY slow, especially because it loads everything when I just need a couple of modules.

I was expecting to see this on the issues list, but I couldn't really find anything.

Is there any plans to have a selective module loading and, maybe, a way of avoiding reload for each instance of the task in the same pipeline? (I am not sure of the technical limitations here)

### Sample Case
I have a pipeline that users AzurePowerShell at the beginning to get some data from a Key Vault, executes a bunch of other procedures and another AzurePowerShell at the end to save some data to a Storage Account Table.

In this case, I would only need to load the Key Vault Module (and dependencies) at the beginning I would only need to load the Storage Module (and dependencies)

data.title: "workingDirectory" parameter seems to be ignored for DotNetCoreCLI@2  "dotnet restore" task
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLI@2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    
## Issue Description

Running build (for example) with the following configuration specifying a workingDirectory works as expected:

```
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  inputs:
    command: 'build'
    workingDirectory: 'src'
```

but running restore with the following similar configuration fails to find a project / solution file

```
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  inputs:
    command: 'restore'
    workingDirectory: 'src'
```
This fails with:

```
MSBUILD : error MSB1003: Specify a project or solution file. The current working directory does not contain a project or solution file.
```

It seems as if the restore task is ignoring the workingDirectory parameter

### Task logs

```
[command]"C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe" restore --configfile d:\a\1\Nuget\tempNuGet_31.config --verbosity Detailed
MSBUILD : error MSB1003: Specify a project or solution file. The current working directory does not contain a project or solution file.
##[error]Error: The process 'C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe' failed with exit code 1
##[error]Packages failed to restore
##[section]Finishing: DotNetCoreCLI

```

### Error logs

```
MSBUILD : error MSB1003: Specify a project or solution file. The current working directory does not contain a project or solution file.
```

data.title: AddBuildTag - fails when there're special characters in the build tag
data.body:
We set build tags with the name of the author and branch to improve the discoverability. 

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/99ba88baac37e1c2b912f64a004bce6b5bc58db5/build/vsts_build.yaml#L56-L57

This doesn't work when the author's name has special characters: 

For example: `o`

Note that the content is escaped:

```yaml
  - task: PowerShell@1
    displayName: "Add Build Tags"
    inputs:
      scriptType: "inlineScript"
      inlineScript: |
        Write-Host "##vso[build.addbuildtag]${env:BUILD_SOURCEVERSIONAUTHOR}"
        Write-Host "##vso[build.addbuildtag]${env:BUILD_SOURCEBRANCHNAME}"
```

data.title: Provide DTAExecutionHost and TestResultsPublisher documentation & sources
data.body:
Please provide documentation, or ideally open source these tools. You are heavily using it for example for running tests and it seems that quite a lot of useful logic is in it, which we would like to be able to use in our custom tasks. 

Example: We need to publish test results where some tests were successful on rerun, meaning we have 2 *.trx files. The results are the same as from the VsTestV2 task (we even tried to use the exact results from the aforementioned task), but publishing them so that they correctly report reruns is beyond our capabilities as the standard approach through PublishTestResultsV2 cannot achieve that and neither TestPublisher from Node SDK can as it is merely a wrapper over 'results.publish' command, which seems quite limited. Any other effort is soiled, because we keep hitting the walls of these 2 magical black boxes. Honestly I'm 99% sure that the whole rerunning & correct test results reporting in VsTestV2 is handled by the DTAExecutionHost. So I want to know if and how the correct rerun test results reporting from the *.trx files could be achieved through TestResultsPublisher (which, looking at the DLLs, I'm afraid it won't), or whether DTAExecutionHost can be used to achieve this (which I hope it might).

This is not the first time I'm almost at the point of disassembling these tools just to learn something about them, which is why I created such a general request even though the example I used is quite specific and will be addressed separately. 

I have the support ticket open for the aforementioned example and am not sure if this is the correct channel to ask for this, but it is closely related to either this, or the SDK directly, so I decided to start here. Please feel free to direct me to better channel to place this request if there is any.

Thanks!

data.title: Xcpretty arguments and test run names in Xcode Task
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Xcode  

I've opened a PR the adds two optional inputs to the Xcode task.

* Setting the name of the test run when publishing the test results.
* Pass additional parameters to xcpretty
The reasons behind needing these changes:

* Currently the test run name is JUnit_TestResults_XXX this isn't helpful if you have multiple tests in the same build. At Tesco we have a nightly build that runs all the tests on iOS 12 and 11 each. Atm it's hard to distinguish which one is which. So it would be good to provide a custom name to disambiguate.
* it would be good to use a customer formatter (specifically https://github.com/Jon889/xcpretty-azure-pipelines-formatter) so that the output is a little friendlier for Azure Pipelines.

The contributing docs mention opening an issue as well.

data.title: Add option for xcpretty arguments and test run name in Xcode Task
data.body:
Adds two optional inputs to the Xcode task.

* Setting the name of the test run when publishing the test results.
* Pass additional parameters to xcpretty

The reasons behind needing these changes:

* Currently the test run name is `JUnit_TestResults_XXX` this isn't helpful if you have multiple tests in the same build. At Tesco we have a nightly build that runs all the tests on iOS 12 and 11 each. Atm it's hard to distinguish which one is which. So it would be good to provide a custom name to disambiguate.
* it would be good to use a customer formatter (specifically https://github.com/Jon889/xcpretty-azure-pipelines-formatter) so that the output is a little friendlier for Azure Pipelines.

I tried to add tests for these new inputs, but couldn't quite work out how to do it.

Also the contribute doc mentions adding a label and assigning a reviewer, but that doesn't seem to be possible.

data.title: MavenV3 Task - JaCoCo coverage is missing on SonarQube
data.body:
## Required Information

*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: MavenV3

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines - https://dev.azure.com/fusionfabric/pegazus/_build/results?buildId=33545

- Agent - Private: microsoft/vsts-agent:ubuntu-16.04-docker-17.12.0-ce-standard

## Issue Description

Similar issue was raised for custom Gradle build https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/10271

This issue is specifically for Maven build with MavenV3 plugin for Azure Pipelines. It does not replicate on my local workstation and on on premise Jenkins CI server.

We have fairly standard reporting for Java project:

- `maven-surefire-plugin` runs unit test
- `maven-failsafe-plugin` runs integration tests
- two report files are generated for jacoco: `./target/jacoco.exec` and `./target/jacoco-it.exec`

Locally, I would run it like this ` mvn  sonar:sonar  -Dsonar.branch.name=support/coverage -Dsonar.host.url=*** -Dsonar.login=*** -Pjenkins,coverage,platform-start,docs,uxp,-dev -B -U -e -Dsonar.jacoco.itReportPath=`pwd`/target/jacoco-it.exec  -Dsonar.jacoco.reportPath=`pwd`/target/jacoco.exec` and get 50% of coverage on SonarQube.

On Azure Pipelines I have configured Maven Task like that

```yaml
      - task: Maven@3 # https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/maven?view=vsts
        displayName: 'Maven build pom.xml'
        inputs:
          mavenPomFile: 'pom.xml'
          goals: clean install
          options: -Pjenkins,coverage,platform-start,docs,uxp,-dev -B -U -e 
          codeCoverageToolOption: JaCoCo
          codeCoverageClassFilter: ""
          codeCoverageSourceDirectories: 
          mavenAuthenticateFeed: true
          sonarQubeRunAnalysis: true
          skipEffectivePom: true
```

But what actually get run on Azure is this `/usr/share/maven/bin/mvn -f /var/vsts/work/1/s/pom.xml -B -s /var/vsts/work/_temp/settings.xml -Pjenkins,coverage,platform-start,platform-stop,docs,uxp,-dev -U -e -fae clean install -Dsonar.jacoco.reportPaths=/var/vsts/work/1/s/CCReport43F6D5EF/jacoco.exec org.sonarsource.scanner.maven:sonar-maven-plugin:RELEASE:sonar`

So both IT and UT results seem to be arbitrarily appended to file named `CCReport43F6D5EF/jacoco.exec` which is out of Maven conventions.

I am not sure, how exactly this appending works, but resulting `jacoco.exec` file does not contain all needed coverage information. 

```
2019-07-17T07:57:33.5133678Z [INFO] parsing [/var/vsts/work/1/s/benchmark/benchmark-connect/target/surefire-reports]
2019-07-17T07:57:33.5160359Z [INFO] Sensor SurefireSensor [java] (done) | time=2ms
2019-07-17T07:57:33.5161129Z [INFO] Sensor JaCoCoSensor [java]
2019-07-17T07:57:33.5162159Z [INFO] JaCoCo UT report not found: '${session.executionRootDirectory}/target/jacoco.exec'
2019-07-17T07:57:33.5162990Z [INFO] JaCoCo IT report not found: '${session.executionRootDirectory}/target/jacoco-it.exec'
2019-07-17T07:57:33.5163548Z [INFO] Analysing /var/vsts/work/1/s/CCReport43F6D5EF/jacoco.exec
2019-07-17T07:57:33.5192820Z [INFO] No information about coverage per test.
```

JaCoCo shows no information about coverage, and on SonarQube final coverage is 0.5% (instead of 50%)

### Task logs

Example for one of the modules (it is multi-module project)

data.title: MavenV3 Task - skipping effective pom does not work
data.body:
## Required Information


*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: MavenV3

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines 

- Agent - Private: microsoft/vsts-agent:ubuntu-16.04-docker-17.12.0-ce-standard
    
## Issue Description

Regardless of parameters set, Task will try to run  `help:effective-pom` Maven goal, which seems to be enabled by default and takes about 1/3 of the total build time (_e.g._ 5 minutes out of 15).

As per docs https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/maven?view=azure-devops

Neither 

```yaml
- task: Maven@3
  inputs:
    effectivePomSkip: false 
```

nor

```yaml
- task: Maven@3
  inputs:
    skipEffectivePom: false 
```

seems to work



data.title: Allow Docker tasks to enable experimental features for manifest support
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Docker

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

To publish multi-architecture Docker manifests, you need to enable the experimental features on the CLI. The current Docker tasks don't allow that to happen.

This is a challenge since you can use the Docker task to handle all the authentication, but then you can't easily modify that configuration (which includes the tokens, etc.). It forces you back into a manual handling of credentials.

Current workaround is to use a shell script like:

```sh
cat $DOCKER_CONFIG/config.json | jq '. + { "experimental": "enabled" }' > $DOCKER_CONFIG/experimental.json
mv -f $DOCKER_CONFIG/experimental.json $DOCKER_CONFIG/config.json
```

data.title: DotNetCoreCLI - Pack missing doc & wierd usage
data.body:
## Note  
This could be related to issue #9789

## Required Information
**Question, Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature  / Cleaning
**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLIV2

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines    
- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description
DotNetCoreCLI@2 provide a documented way for packing, who is _I think_ mispelling / hard to get into / easier to get lost.

Like: 
```yaml
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  displayName: 'Pack - Manager'
  inputs:
    command: 'pack'
    projects: '$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/src/CM/CM.csproj'
    includesymbols: true
    includesource: true
    nobuild: true
    verbosityPack: 'normal'
    outputDir: '$(Build.StagingDirectory)'
```
`projects` won't be used during `pack` cmd and will be override by `searchPatternPack` who is _required_ but has a default. And it seem to have one alias [`packagesToPack`](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/94206c8e95afe6a50ca671869157d0c19c144cd4/Tasks/DotNetCoreCLIV2/task.json#L328) who is not set or documented.

data.title: Index Sources & Publish Symbols doesn't allow SymbolsVersion when SymbolServerType is TeamServices
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Question (possible bug)

**Enter Task Name**: Index Sources & Publish Symbols

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/PublishSymbolsV2/PublishSymbols.ps1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
    Azure Pipelines

    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: Not relevant


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 

    Hosted

## Issue Description

When using the setting `symbolServerType: TeamServices`, the Index Sources & Publish Symbols task doesn't allow passing the `symbolsVersion`. It *assumes* that the `Build.BuildNumber` will be the correct version to use.

Which version is *supposed* to be used for publishing symbols?

1. The same version as the NuGet package
2. The Build.BuildNumber of Azure Pipelines
3. One of the other MSBuild properties (InformationalVersion, FileVersion, or AssemblyVersion)

In my case, the number populated in `Build.BuildNumber` is NOT the same as the NuGet package version. 

Example:

```
Build.BuildNumber: 1.7.3-foo-bar.3+4266a43d09
PackageVersion:    1.7.3-foo-bar.3.4266a43d09
```

So, if the NuGet package version is supposed to be what is in there, the task should allow the `Build.BuildNumber` to be overridden [here](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/PublishSymbolsV2/PublishSymbols.ps1#L167).

It would be helpful if the documentation [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/index-sources-publish-symbols?view=azure-devops) and/or [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/artifacts/symbols?view=azure-devops) made it clear which version to use, or whether it matters. At the very least, it should specify that some of the parameters are not used when specifying `TeamServices`.

data.title: Fix temporary nuget config file issue in Restore command
data.body:
NugetConfigHelper2 creates temporary nuget fie (if doesn't exist) in build directory and doesn't clean-up. So if 2 restore task is used then temporary nuget config file is not created for the second restore task and it uses the existing one, which is wrong.

Fix -> Delete the file if exists before creating path in NugetConfigHelper2.

data.title: Deploy Cloud Service using ARM Storage Account
data.body:
**Question**  
Is it possible for the Azure Cloud Service Deployment task to support Storage Accounts created by ARM?

**Enter Task Name**: AzureCloudPowerShellDeploymentV1

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureCloudPowerShellDeploymentV1

## Environment
Azure Pipelines
- Agent 
Hosted or Private, same issue.

## Issue Description
Currently, deploying to Azure Cloud Services requires a classic storage account in order for the deployment to work.  We have been able to move all of our storage accounts to ARM with the exception of the classic storage accounts needed for the Cloud Services deployment. 

**Azure Advisor** continually recommends migrating classic storage accounts to ARM based storage accounts. There's no way to selectively dismiss this recommendation \ warning based on resource ID or name. I can disable this particular policy that performs this scan, but then that will disable it for my entire subscription (which I really don't want to do as ARM is what we want to use in all cases). 

This issue was raised before (see: https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/3683) and closed, but I am wondering if this can be revisited or perhaps a V2 version created that will allow the usage of a ARM storage account while deploying Cloud Services?

data.title: Using path environment variables on windows image in bash task problematic
data.body:
Bug/Enhancement
Azure Pipelines, hosted agent

I am using a 'window-latest' vmImage for my hosted pipeline agent and trying to use the bash task to run some scripts.  However, when I use some of the predefined variables containing paths I ran into problems.  For example the `System.DefaultWorkingDirectory` variable returned something like `d:\a\s\1`, but then when used from within bash the backslashes got removed (as they were treated like escape chars) and I ended up with the path `d:as1`.

I ended up resorting to a sed script to convert the Windows path to a POSIX one:

```yaml
    - bash: |
        working_dir=$(echo "$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory") | sed 's/\\/\//g' | sed 's|\([a-zA-Z]\):|/\1|')
        cd $working_dir/Subdir
        ./scripts/run_tests.sh
```

Would it be possible for the bash task to recognise env. vars that are paths and convert them to a POSIX-friendly version in this circumstance - to save the nasty regex?

data.title: no matching key exchange method found.

labels.name: backlog
labels.description: Work that is on the backlog and won't get marked stale

data.body:
I am trying to copy my build Artifacts to my Linux Server using azure-piplines and this task:
```
- task: CopyFilesOverSSH@0
  inputs:
    sshEndpoint: 'pillbox'
    sourceFolder: '$(build.artifactstagingdirectory)'
    contents: 'AmiKoWindows/bin/Release/Amiko-Installer/Amiko-Installer.msi'
    targetFolder: '/home/ftp/Amiko_Desitin_Win7.msi'
```
The SSH Copy-Job always fails. My SSH log on the receiving end says:
```
Jun 12 16:02:15 [sshd] Unable to negotiate with 137.135.130.50 port 1984: no matching key exchange method found. Their offer: ecdh-sha2-nistp256,ecdh-sha2-nistp384,ecdh-sha2-nistp521,diffie-hellman-group-exchange-sha256,diffie-hellman-group14-sha1 [preauth]
```
I use `Ed25519` which is the most recommended public-key algorithm available [today](https://medium.com/risan/upgrade-your-ssh-key-to-ed25519-c6e8d60d3c54).

any thoughts on when Azure-Pipeline-Tasks may support that? The offered key exchange methods seem a bit outdated AFAICT.

You can find the build here: https://dev.azure.com/ywesee/AmiKo_Csharp/_build/results?buildId=33

This may be related: #8818, https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/vsts-docs/issues/3169

data.title: [Feature Request] AzureFunctionApp Management Group Service Connector Support

labels.name: Area: AzureAppService
labels.description: Label to monitor Azure App Service issues

data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
Feature

**Enter Task Name**: AzureFunctionApp

## Issue Description

The AzureFunctionApp should support the Management Group service connector option, so that one service connection can be used to deploy to multiple subscriptions.

Azure Function App names have to be globally unique so it should by default search all connected subscriptions in the management group for the "appName", but an optional azureSubscriptionId parameter should be supplied so that a specific subscription can be specified if required.

In the unexpected case of an appname duplicate result, it should error and indicate to the user that they should set azureSubscriptionId to the specific subscription they want.

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?  Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted or Private: Hosted

## Issue Description

I'm guessing you could reproduce the bug this way:

- Create a C# xUnit test project
- Add a failing unit test with a display name (example below)
- Run the test in Azure Pipeline using the VsTestv2 task
- Enable the **Rerun failed tests** option
- Observe the following:
  - The build/release is green / passes
  - However looking at the Tests output there is a failing test
  - The output, in the `Rerunning failed tests` section shows an incorrect test filter and 0 test were run
    - The test filter is trying to use the Display Name in the FullyQualifiedName.

```
[Fact(DisplayName = "My failing test")]
public void TheProblematicTest() => throw new Exception();
```

The correct behavior would obviously be to find and run the failed test. However you should also do a sanity check and check for output similar to `No test matches the given testcase filter` or check the number of tests run matches the number expected.

This issue is similar to #7003 but that issue did not involve a display name, so I believe it is a different bug. Also I encountered this today, so it has not been fixed.

data.title: KubernetesV1 creating secret also runs extra command that generates error
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: KubernetesV1

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines 

Error build
https://dev.azure.com/lgmdevops/Security/_build/results?buildId=33784&view=logs&j=3dc8fd7e-4368-5a92-293e-d53cefc8c4b3

Good build
https://dev.azure.com/lgmdevops/Security/_build/results?buildId=33792&view=logs&j=3dc8fd7e-4368-5a92-293e-d53cefc8c4b3

- Agent - Private: 
Windows 10 1903

## Issue Description

Documentation states the task should be used like this to create a secret:
    - task: Kubernetes@1
      displayName: secretType generic with literal values
      inputs:
        azureSubscriptionEndpoint: $(azureSubscriptionEndpoint)
        azureResourceGroup: $(azureResourceGroup)
        kubernetesCluster: $(kubernetesCluster)
        command: apply
        arguments: -f mhc-aks.yaml
        secretType: generic
        secretArguments: --from-literal=contoso=5678
        secretName: mysecretkey

Reviewing the output from the task shows that it is attempting to run a second command after creating the secret.

PS > \ProgramData\chocolatey\bin\kubectl.exe create secret generic signing-cert --from-file=./deploy/signingcert.pem
secret/signing-cert created
PS > \ProgramData\chocolatey\bin\kubectl.exe apply -o json
error: must specify one of -f and -k
##[error]C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\bin\kubectl.exe failed with return code: 1

Removing the 'command' allows the task to complete successfully. 

Perhaps we need a 'secret' command?

### Task logs

failed logs attached
[12_Create k8s signing cert secret.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/files/3249601/12_Create.k8s.signing.cert.secret.txt)

data.title: ServiceFabricUpdateManifestsV2 does not update ImageOverrides with the correct docker settings
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: ServiceFabricUpdateManifestsV2

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/7e2d65456791dd520f9840c656a8df292b2cd65a/Tasks/ServiceFabricUpdateManifestsV2/Update-DockerImageSettings.psm1#L86

## Environment
- Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

Service Fabric allows overriding the Image Name depending on the target OS of the node being deployed - this is available by adding different images in the ImageOverrides node of the Application Manifest XML.

The current implementation of the ServiceFabricUpdateManifestsV2 updates the Image name in the ServiceManifest with the correct tag, however, it does not update the ImageOverrides

data.title: DotNetCoreCLI should not default to publishWebProjects or zipAfterPublish.
data.body:
## Note  

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

Type: Feature

**DotNetCoreCLIV2**: 

## Issue Description

DotNetCoreCLI should not have publishWebProjects or zipAfterPublish defaulting to true. Both are extremely surprising as a first-time user. The former is outright broken for any projects that don't follow the web convention. (The error message is also extremely unhelpful.) The latter made me waste a couple hours wondering why I was doing a publish but my publish directory was missing.

Obviously this means bumping to version 3 but I think it would be a great change to make the task easier to use. (As it is, all of my publish commands have publishWebProjects: False.)
